facts.text: Writ Petition No. 120 of 1959 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition No. 120 of 1959. Writ Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 7, 1961 by SARKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 7. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.-

facts.text: Petitioner is a dealer registered under the Punjab General Sales Tax Act

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is a dealer registered under the Punjab General Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: Petitioner filed returns of sale turnovers for four quarters of financial year ending March 31, 1955

anchor.surface_text: He filed returns of his sale turnovers for the four quarters of the financial year ending on March 31, 1955,

facts.text: Petitioner filed returns of sale turnovers for four quarters of financial year ending March 31, 1956

anchor.surface_text: and likewise, for the four quarters of the financial year ending on March 31, 1956.

facts.text: Sales Tax Assessing Officer served three successive notices on petitioner on March 7, 1958, April 4, 1958, and August 18, 1959

anchor.surface_text: In respect of each year the Sales Tax Assessing Officer served three successive notices on him on March 7, 1958, April 4, 1958, and August 18, 1959,

facts.text: Notices required petitioner to attend with documents and evidence in support of returns

anchor.surface_text: requiring him to attend with the documents and other evidence in support of his returns.

facts.text: Last notice on August 18, 1959 stated that failure to produce documents would lead to best judgment assessment

anchor.surface_text: In the last of the notices mentioned above it was stated that on failure to produce the documents and other evidence mentioned, the case would be decided on best judgment assessment basis.

facts.text: Petitioner did not comply with any of the notices

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner did not comply with any of the notices,

facts.text: Petitioner presented this petition under Art. 32 after receipt of the last notice challenging right to best judgment assessment

anchor.surface_text: but after the receipt of the last notice he presented this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution challenging the right of the authorities to make a best judgment assessment.

facts.text: Assessing officer had not proceeded to make any assessment on petitioner at the date of any of the notices

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that the assessing officer had not proceeded to make any assessment on the petitioner at the date of any of the notices.

facts.text: Learned counsel for respondent conceded that petitioner's contention is well founded

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the respondent, the assessing authority, also frankly conceded that he found it difficult to contend to the contrary.

facts.text: Petitioner contends that at date of last notice, authorities had no right to best judgment assessment as three years had expired

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the petitioner is that at the date of the notice last mentioned the Sales Tax authorities had no right to proceed to make any best judgment assessment as the three years...

facts.text: Court finds petitioner's contention well founded

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the contention of the petitioner is well founded.

facts.text: No best judgment assessment could be made after March 31, 1959 for quarters ending March 31, 1956

anchor.surface_text: So the assessing authority could not proceed to make a best judgment assessment in respect of this quarter after March 31, 1959.

facts.text: Petition allowed and writ issued restraining respondent from making best judgment assessment for quarters of financial years 1955 and 1956

anchor.surface_text: The petition must, therefore, be allowed. A writ will issue restraining the respondent from making any best judgment assessment on the petitioner for sales tax for any quarter of the financial years 1955 and 1956.

facts.text: Registered dealers furnish returns quarterly under r.20 of rules

anchor.surface_text: Under r. 20 of these rules, a registered dealer like the petitioner, had to furnish returns quarterly.

facts.text: Bhagirath Das and B. P. Maheshwari appeared for petitioner

anchor.surface_text: Bhagirath Das and, B. P. Maheshwari, for the petitioner.

facts.text: S. Bindra and D. Gupta appeared for respondent

anchor.surface_text: S. Bindra and D. Gupta, for the respondent.

facts.text: Three years for best judgment assessment counted from end of each quarter

anchor.surface_text: We come to this that the three years within which the authority could proceed to make the best judgment assessment had to be counted from the end of each quarter...
Writ Petition No. 120 of 1959. Writ Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.
but after the receipt of the last notice he presented this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution challenging the right of the authorities to make a best judgment assessment.

The contention of the petitioner is that at the date of the notice last mentioned the Sales Tax authorities had no right to proceed to make any best judgment assessment as the three years within which only such assessment could be made had expired before then. It seems to us that the contention of the petitioner is well founded.

concepts.interpretation: The three years within which best judgment assessment can be made under sub-section (4) must be computed from the expiry of the return period (quarter) in respect of which returns were furnished.

issues.text: Whether the Sales Tax authorities had the right to proceed to make any best judgment assessment at the date of the last notice, as the three years within which such assessment could be made had expired

anchor.surface_text: but after the receipt of the last notice he presented this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution challenging the right of the authorities to make a best judgment assessment. The contention of the petitioner is that at the date of the notice last mentioned the Sales Tax authorities had no right to proceed to make any best judgment assessment as the three years within which only such assessment could be made had expired before then. It s

issues.text: How to compute the three years within which best judgment assessment can be made under sub-section (4) of s. 11 of the Punjab General Sales Tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the respondent, the assessing authority, also frankly conceded that he found it difficult to contend to the contrary. Sub-section  4  of s. 11 deals with the case of a dealer who has furnished returns in respect of a period and has thereafter been asked to produce evidence to support the returns but has failed to do so. The sub-section provides that in such a case the assessing authority may proceed to make an assessment which to the best of his judgment should be made irrespective of the returns. The reason for this provision is that the correctness of the returns having been doubted by the assessing authority, the dealer has not availed himself of the opportunity afforded to him to remove these doubts. The sub-section however provides that the power can be exercised within the three years mentioned in it. Quite plainly, the power cannot be exercised after these three years have gone by. The question is, how to compute the three years?

arguments.claim: At the date of the notice last mentioned the Sales Tax authorities had no right to proceed to make any best judgment assessment as the three years within which only such assessment could be made had expired before then

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the petitioner is that at the date of the notice last mentioned the Sales Tax authorities had no right to proceed to make any best judgment assessment as the three years within which only such assessment could be made had expired before then.

arguments.court_reasoning: Contention well founded; statutory interpretation confirms three-year period computed from end of each quarter, expired before last notice

arguments.claim: Found it difficult to contend to the contrary to petitioner's contention

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the respondent, the assessing authority, also frankly conceded that he found it difficult to contend to the contrary.

arguments.claim: The period referred therefore is the period mentioned earlier in the sub-section, and that is the period in respect of which returns had been furnished by the dealer

anchor.surface_text: The sub- section says within three years after the expiry of such period. So the three years have to be counted from the expiry of the period mentioned. What then is that period? The words are such period. The period referred therefore is the period mentioned earlier. in the sub-section, and that is the period in respect of which returns had been furnished by the dealer.

arguments.claim: Under r. 20 ... a registered dealer like the petitioner, had to furnish returns quarterly. ... that refers ... to the quarters in respect of which he submitted the returns

anchor.surface_text: Now s. 10 3  provides that every registered dealer shall furnish such returns by such dates and to such authority as may be prescribed Prescribed means prescribed by rules framed under the Act. Under r. 20 of these rules, a registered dealer like the petitioner, had to furnish returns quarterly. The rules define return period as the period for which returns are prescribed to be furnished by a dealer. It would therefore appear that when sub-sec.  4  of s. 11 talks of returns in respect of a period, that refers in the case of the petitioner to the quarters in respect of which he submitted the returns. We come to this that the three years within which the authority could proceed to make the best judgment assessment had to be counted from the end of each quarter...

arguments.claim: the assessing authority could not proceed to make a best judgment assessment in respect of this quarter after March 31, 1959

anchor.surface_text: So the assessing authority could not proceed to make a best judgment assessment in respect of this quarter after March 31, 1959.

arguments.claim: the notices given on August 18, 1959, that best judgment assessments would be made in respect of the quarters constituting the financial years 1955 and 1956 ... were futile. No such assessments could be made in respect of any of these quarters after March 31, 1959

anchor.surface_text: In the case of the earlier quarters, of course, the three years had expired even prior to this date. It is not in dispute that the assessing officer had not proceeded to make any assessment on the petitioner at the date of any of the notices. In the present case therefore the notices given on August 18, 1959, that best judgment assessments would be made in respect of the quarters constituting the financial years 1955 and 1956, the last of which expired on March 31, 1956, were futile. No such assessments could be made in respect of any of these quarters after March 31, 1959.

holdings.text: It seems to us that the contention of the petitioner is well founded.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the contention of the petitioner is well founded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's claim accepted as limitation under s.11(4) had expired before last notice.

holdings.text: The period referred therefore is the period mentioned earlier in the sub-section, and that is the period in respect of which returns had been furnished by the dealer.

anchor.surface_text: The sub- section says within three years after the expiry of such period. So the three years have to be counted from the expiry of the period mentioned. What then is that period? The words are such period. The period referred therefore is the period mentioned earlier. in the sub-section, and that is the period in respect of which returns had been furnished by the dealer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation: 'such period' in s.11(4) refers to the return period mentioned earlier in the section.

holdings.text: when sub-sec. 4 of s. 11 talks of returns in respect of a period, that refers in the case of the petitioner to the quarters in respect of which he submitted the returns.

anchor.surface_text: Now s. 10 3  provides that every registered dealer shall furnish such returns by such dates and to such authority as may be prescribed Prescribed means prescribed by rules framed under the Act. Under r. 20 of these rules, a registered dealer like the petitioner, had to furnish returns quarterly. The rules define return period as the period for which returns are prescribed to be furnished by a dealer. It would therefore appear that when sub-sec. 4  of s. 11 talks of returns in respect of a period, that refers in the case of the petitioner to the quarters in respect of which he submitted the returns. We come to this that the three years within which the authority could proceed to make the best judgment assessment had to be counted from the end of each quarter...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction with s.10(3) and r.20: return period is quarterly.

holdings.text: the three years within which the authority could proceed to make the best judgment assessment had to be counted from the end of each quarter in respect of which returns had been filed.

anchor.surface_text: We come to this that the three years within which the authority could proceed to make the best judgment assessment had to be counted from the end of each quarter in respect of which returns had been filed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conclusion from textual and harmonious reading of s.11(4), s.10(3), r.20.

holdings.text: the assessing authority could not proceed to make a best judgment assessment in respect of this quarter after March 31, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: So the assessing authority could not proceed to make a best judgment assessment in respect of this quarter after March 31, 1959.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of limitation to last quarter ending March 31, 1956.

holdings.text: the notices given on August 18, 1959, that best judgment assessments would be made in respect of the quarters constituting the financial years 1955 and 1956, the last of which expired on March 31, 1956, were futile. No such assessments could be made in respect of any of these quarters after March 31, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of the earlier quarters, of course, the three years had expired even prior to this date. It is not in dispute that the assessing officer had not proceeded to make any assessment on the petitioner at the date of any of the notices. In the present case therefore the notices given on August 18, 1959, that best judgment assessments would be made in respect of the quarters constituting the financial years 1955 and 1956, the last of which expired on March 31, 1956, were futile. No such assessments could be made in respect of any of these quarters after March 31, 1959.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notices post-limitation; no prior assessment; periods expired.

holdings.text: The petition must, therefore, be allowed. A writ will issue restraining the respondent from making any best judgment assessment on the petitioner for sales tax for any quarter of the financial years 1955 and 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The petition must, therefore, be allowed. A writ will issue restraining the respondent from making any best judgment assessment on the petitioner for sales tax for any quarter of the financial years 1955 and 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Authorities lack power due to expiration of limitation period under s.11(4).
